Posts.Content: jlmacy wrote: I don't post very often but enjoy reading all the comments and gaining information. I am having my third CT scan and second bone scan tomorrow. Had mastectomy June 2 with clear margins but surgeon emphasized that this was not a "curative measure". I have not had any chemotherapy or radiation but have been on Femara since September 2010 diagnosis. I have been having physical therapy for adhesions and the therapist could not believe that I am stage IV. She says our skin is the window to our health and that the skin around my incision looks very healthy. She feels that the excessive scar tissue is my body's way of fighting any tumor recurrence. I am hoping for NED but would be happy with stable and no progression. Not necessarily looking for any answers just the support that all of you always give.... Dx 9/14/2010, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 9/16/2010 Femara (letrozole) Surgery 6/1/2011 Mastectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 11/3/2011 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Hormonal Therapy 3/9/2012 Chemotherapy 5/31/2012 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 5/2/2013 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Radiation Therapy 1/29/2014 Brain Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scans tomorrow jlmacy jlmacy

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 10:24AM jlmacy wrote: Thanks so much to all of you for the kind words of encouragement. Unfortunately I did not hear from my oncologist; I have a follow up appointment next Friday to go over the results, but I thought I might hear from her so I was not left hanging. So I am hoping that no news is good news but in the back of my mind I am wondering that she might want to break the bad news to me in person. Guess I'll find out soon.
Posts.Title: Scans tomorrow jlmacy jlmacy

Posts.Content: jlmacy wrote: First of all I would like to say that although I am not a frequent poster, I have gained so much knowledge and hope from all of you wonderful ladies and I am truly grateful. I had scans last week, spent the last seven days in scanxiety before seeing my oncologist today. I had a feeling that the news would not be good...I was on Femara since diagnosis in September 2010, had mastectomy in June 2011 (to improve my QOL), and switched to Faslodex in November when last scan showed progression in my lung lesions. Well it didn't work. The lung lesions have increased in size (the largest is 1.5cm) but thankfully there are no new ones and it hasn't gone anywhere else. Although I didn't have any bad side effects from the Faslodex, my biggest disappointment is that I have wasted a great deal of $$ (I have a $2500 deductible) on a treatment for four months that did absolutely nothing. Now I have three options..1) Good ol' bottle of Tamoxifen (just finished reading a host of horror stories including deafness). 2) Try 3 weeks of Taxol. Or 3) a clinical trial with Aromasin and a new drug which is administered in a weekly infusion with the off chance that I would be one of the unlucky ones to get a placebo. I decided to give the Tamoxifen a try and will get scanned again in three months (which will coincidentally be around the one year anniversary of my mastectomy). I feel comfortable with my decision but of course would like some input. Thanks, Joanie Dx 9/14/2010, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 9/16/2010 Femara (letrozole) Surgery 6/1/2011 Mastectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 11/3/2011 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Hormonal Therapy 3/9/2012 Chemotherapy 5/31/2012 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 5/2/2013 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Radiation Therapy 1/29/2014 Brain Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Not the greatest news.. jlmacy alesta29

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 09:31AM jlmacy wrote: I started taking Cymbalta a few months ago for neuropathy. It is almost completely gone in my fingers but still persists in my toes and feet. I have been off chemo since November so that could be the reason for the improvement. I have noticed that I am a lot more achy if I forget to take it so it might be helping my arthritis pain. It has made me have lots of vivid crazy dreams!! I take it in the morning with my blood pressure meds.
Posts.Title: cymbalta for pain bhd1 TXGigi

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 03:10PM jlmacy wrote: Hi Lynn, It's okay to be scared. I had to walk into the OR and get on the table for both hysterectomy and mastectomy. For port they slid me over! I'll be thinking of you tomorrow and wishing you the best. Please let us now how you are doing! Joanie
Posts.Title: Port Questions Lynn1 CelineFlower

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 11:13PM jlmacy wrote: Hi everyone - Well I'm happy to say that my first port experience went remarkably well. I was trying to post a message during my infusion but between the benadryl and the temperamental keypad on my tablet, I was having a hard time. Lynn-even though the area around my port is bruised and sore, I didn't feel the stick at all. The nurse was very patient and explained everything. I used the Emla cream about an hour before. They told me that it is not uncommon to have discomfort for a few weeks until things heal, so that was reassuring. Maybe it's my imagination, but it actually feels better since it was used. And it was great not to have anything hanging out of my arm and I won't have a bruise. I hope this helps you find your "happy place". I understand how having the port makes it seem like chemo is something "permanent" but in reality it is. I'm glad I had mine placed and I hope you will be, too.  Take care, Joanie
Posts.Title: Port Questions Lynn1 CelineFlower

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2012 01:23AM jlmacy wrote: OMG - I was just checking online to see the status of my many unpaid insurance claims (that's a whole other post) and discovered that my port placement was $18,355.70. Almost as much as a mastectomy!!!
Posts.Title: Port Questions Lynn1 CelineFlower

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 11:33PM jlmacy wrote: Hello I have been following this thread with great interest as I just had my Power Port placed last Friday. Tomorrow will be my first time to have it accessed and I am a little worried. I hadn't posted earlier because I didn't want to scare anyone needlessly but it is still very sore. It hurts to touch around the port itself and if I reach my arm across my chest or squish my chest in any way I get a sharp pain. I have also been awakened with it hurting - ipuprofen does help. I tolerate pain pretty well but I just didn't expect this much soreness, is this normal? Fortunately I see my oncologist tomorrow before my infusion so I will have her look at it. This will be my second round of three weekly Taxol and I am already scoping my arm for a good vein in case they can't use the port. Thanks for any advice, Joanie

I, too have spent a lot of time on that river!

I recently developed  a cough and some slight wheezing. My oncologist seems to think it is due to enlarged lymph nodes in my sternum area rather than the lung nodules. She prescribed a Ventolin inhaler and it helps somewhat. Joanie
Posts.Title: LUNG METS - does the coughing ever stop?? 1701jms Jabid

Posts.Content: jlmacy wrote: Well I saw my oncologist today and got results from my scans a week ago. I have been hoping that "no news is good news" but unfortunately that wasn't the case. I had slight progression in my lung mets (1mm or so) but no new mets so I am NED from the sternum down. I have been on Femara since my diagnosis in September 2010 and am switching to Faslodex. I had my first injection today and I can honestly say it was not all that bad. I usually go to all my appointments alone but my boyfriend (I hate that term) went with me today and it made it easier. Hopefully this will be the answer for a while at least. Looking forward to the cruise we have booked for Christmas! Posts.Title: Got Results jlmacy Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 11:22AM - edited Jun 29, 2012 11:24AM by jlmacy Hi Lynn - it's your port buddy! Somehow I must have missed this post, your feelings about chemo are exactly like mine were. I, too have never felt sick, everyone tells me I "look great", no one can believe that I have Stage IV cancer. I was ready to give up before my last scan because in my heart I knew it would show more progression. I was wrestling with the thoughts of which was worse -dying or suffering through chemo. I didn't want to be a burden, I was afraid that I wouldn't be able to work or enjoy doing the things I love. I especially did not want to start chemo in the summer. Last summer was a wash out because of my mastectomy and susequent weeks of physical therapy. I want to tell you what happened that changed my mind, improved my attitude and got me in the right mind-set. I have been lucky to have gotten involved and friendly with a great group of people (the common denominator is the local pub). We have frequent cook outs and get togethers. There are a few of the women who have been especially kind and supportive to me with this cancer deal. Anyway, the day before my last scan, I sent them all an e-mail telling them how much I appreciated their kindness and what it meant to me. I didn't expect anything in return, but the response I got from each of them was overwhelming. Suddenly I knew my life was important, that I was loved and appreciated and I knew I couldn't give up. It was one of the greatest gifts I have been given. I don't know if this will help you get your "glass full" back but I hope it will somehow. You sound like you have a lot of inner strength, just keep telling that to yourself. BTW the port feel so much better today since it got tapped! You can get throught that, too! I'm not a hugger either so here's a high five!! Joanie

Posts.Title: NED is still loving me!!! :-) JeninMichigan sarah1968uk

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2013 02:56PM jlmacy wrote: Hi Cheryl I have a similar story...and like you I decided to try the Tamoxifen for 3 months. My other choices were a blind clinical trial or Taxol. In my heart, I knew the Tamoxifen was not going to work but I dreaded the idea of going on chemo. After 3 months I had continued progression and had no choice but to go with chemo. I had 18 infusions of Taxol over 24 weeks (3 weeks on and 1 week off). My last one was November 2; I have had 3 scans since then and I am still stable and currently not undergoing any treatment. If I had it to do over again, I would have skipped the Tamoxifen and gone straight for the Taxol. Good luck with whatever decision you choose. No matter what, progression is tough and starting any new treatment is always scary. Joanie
Posts.Title: Faslodex didn't work cheryl1946 susan_02143

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2014 11:00AM jlmacy wrote: I don't post that often, but I recently discovered mets have gone to my brain so I have been scanning the brain mets forums. I had some seizures on January 29, 2014, spent six days in hospital, and had a total of 15 WBR treatments. I also had steroid psychosis with hallucinations. I, too experienced an overwhelming sense of peace and was no longer afraid. I am not a religious person, but I could feel the positive energy surrounding me and I felt safe. I remember reciting the 23rd psalm while lying on the radiation table. "Be not afraid for thou are't with me"
